Posts.Content: Anyone...ask me how my Labor Day weekend has gone thus far...OK, I'll tell you anyway...well, the Crimson Tide won, but that's not the high point...I'm 6 weeks postop today...and yesterday I was invited to play a little softball...I didn't go all out, as I am still moving a little slow, but I did go 2 for 4, so that was a plus...BUT...the absolute high point came last night...yes, THAT happened...my wife & I were a bit concerned, what with all the info we had received relating to being able to have sex after the DaVinci surgery...we were convinced that we were looking at a much longer wait...but no, we didn't have to wait...we've been married 33 years and last night was such a surprise and a wonderful one it was. I achieved one orgasm and it, while different, was still great...I maintained all the way through and my wife enjoyed her usual multi-orgasm experience...we just laid there afterward and all I could say was "wow" over and over again...I owe my wife a huge debt of gratitude for her patience and help during this recovery...and I think my surgeon surely earned his money...very happy!
Posts.Signature: 55 years old (born in 1962) PSA 5.6 (2nd PSA >4 in 12 months) Feb 2015. Biopsy 4/1/15, G (3+3) 6. 1 of 8 sections. Da Vinci surgery 7/27/15, cath removed 8/4/15. First PSA post-op is zero (10/27/15) Second PSA is zero (6/29/16) Third PSA is zero (12/20/16) Fourth PSA is zero (7/1/17) Fifth PSA is zero (1/11/18 virtually no incontinence issues, sex life pretty much back to normal (wife & I are happy with that one )
Posts.Title: Someone ask me how my weekend has been...

Posts.Content: Many thanks for the replies and kind words...we are still moving forward slowly, but so far so good...I don't think we're gonna return to our newlywed days , but we are very encouraged...PDV, I sure do hope all goes well for you...I had one of those Jackson-Pratt drains in post-op and I was very happy to be rid of it when they took it out...I go back to work on Monday, so I'm trying to resist doing stuff around my house that needs to be done, but involves some heavy or semi-heavy lifting...but I'm trying to be heed my wife's reminders. I'm a respiratory therapist, so normally there is not a lot of heavy lifting at work, but I work for a pediatric homecare company, so there is travel involved and some lifting, so I'm gonna have to ease back into it...I figure I'll be doing mostly office stuff and patient/family teaching for the first few weeks. I'm very hopeful that this is the first step to returning to "normalcy".

Posts.Title: Post surgery report

Posts.Content: Many thanks for the well-wishes as well as the input & advice...I will certainly take them to heart...glad to make y'alls acquaintance and I look forward to the interaction...I'm a member of a couple of other forums, both sports related, so this is, as you might imagine, kind of a departure from what I'm accustomed to...all the best!
Posts.Title: New Member/Maiden Voyage

Posts.Content: Hello All...I found this forum this morning and have read a few of the threads...I don't feel quite as isolated as I did. I am quite impressed with the various member's signatures, I guess I'll have to construct mine as time allows, which I have plenty of at current. I had been seeing my urologist for BPH for a couple of years, with PSA's in the low to mid 3's...after a couple of PSAs greater than 4 biopsy was suggested, performed, and confirmed cancer in April of this year. I had DaVinci surgery on 7/27 and the cath was removed 8/4 (4 days ago). Scott Tully, in Birmingham is my surgeon, and thus far I'm very pleased with him and his staff. Still in quite a bit of discomfort as it relates to one of the incision sites (the one on my right side) and of course there is some discomfort, though not a lot of pain, relating to the surgery site inside. I'm using between 3-5 pads per day, but am concerned that I am visiting the bathroom quite often, with very little results. Urination comes pretty freely and quite easily, but, even though my bladder feels full, there is only a small amount of urine...then 20 minutes or so later...time to go again...a pattern that seems to repeat itself for a while. Is this pretty common? I'm not really someone who likes to bug the doctor unless its pretty significant. I'm also a bit confused about the Kegels...I've read about them, and, of course, practiced them prior to the surgery, but post-surgery, I'm still learning about the best time & way to practice them, so this forum has provided some helpful info regarding those. My wife of 33 years is incredibly supportive. I'm hoping to return to work after Labor Day. Sorry for the long post, lots of info to digest here, I suppose. I am grateful to find this forum and, while I obviously would prefer not to be a member of this type of fraternity, I am glad to be among those whose experiences may be similar to mine and that I might be able to learn, and in time, contribute a little too. Many thanks!
Posts.Title: New Member/Maiden Voyage

Posts.Content: Many thanks for the well-wishes as well as the input & advice...I will certainly take them to heart...glad to make y'alls acquaintance and I look forward to the interaction...I'm a member of a couple of other forums, both sports related, so this is, as you might imagine, kind of a departure from what I'm accustomed to...all the best!
Posts.Title: New Member/Maiden Voyage

Posts.Content: Many thanks for all the input & advice...I'm still sorta getting my footing, as it were...but this really helps. You are right, I guess I should have used a different term other than "Maiden Voyage" denoting my first visit to this forum, LOL...but I was tired, last night was not a good one, so I went with it I am keeping the log of pad use and so far its not as bad as I feared, just have to make sure to keep the numbers straight.

Posts.Title: Post-Op Days

Posts.Content: Badman, getting the cath out was the first step to regaining that "back to your old self" feeling for me, and I'm sure others may agree. Once that's behind you, you'll be, hopefully, happily amazed at how much better you feel and how rapidly it happens. I thought the day my cath came out would never arrive, but after it did, the days flew by and, even though it was a matter of taking "baby steps", I was really amazed at how much better I felt, as soon as I did. Hope your recovery goes well...all the best!

Posts.Title: Hello Again and Zero Club Renewal

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F BTW, wish we could say the same about the Red Sox!!! Good luck! Ditto that... BTW...I'm 22 days post-op and 14 days post cath removal...I have had plenty of nights thus far with multiple bathroom trips, but, they are getting less frequent...I'm optimistic that they will continue to diminish. I thought I was losing my mind for a couple of nights...up every hour, pee a little, go back to sleep...repeat over and over...its not as bad, although I do notice a pattern...if I drink tea or coke at night, the caffeine usually makes for a longer night, so I'm trying to limit my caffeine intake after lunch-time. Hope this helps...all the best in your recovery.
Posts.Title: Urge to pee waking me up

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F BTW, wish we could say the same about the Red Sox!!! Good luck! Ditto that... BTW...I'm 22 days post-op and 14 days post cath removal...I have had plenty of nights thus far with multiple bathroom trips, but, they are getting less frequent...I'm optimistic that they will continue to diminish. I thought I was losing my mind for a couple of nights...up every hour, pee a little, go back to sleep...repeat over and over...its not as bad, although I do notice a pattern...if I drink tea or coke at night, the caffeine usually makes for a longer night, so I'm trying to limit my caffeine intake after lunch-time. Hope this helps...all the best in your recovery.
Posts.Title: Urge to pee waking me up

Posts.Content: I'm exactly 3 months post Da Vinci surgery today (7/27 - 10/27), while I was doing some patient teaching my phone rang, it was my urologist office...sorta nervous when I saw the number, but I excused myself to the hallway, took the call, and was quite relieved to hear the report, "...your PSA is zero." I breathed a sigh of relief, text'd my wife, and went back to finishing my day... I had read in this forum when guys would get their results and only now can I fully appreciate the tension and anticipation of getting the results...it was a good feeling. Hoping for more of them.
Posts.Signature: 55 years old (born in 1962) PSA 5.6 (2nd PSA >4 in 12 months) Feb 2015. Biopsy 4/1/15, G (3+3) 6. 1 of 8 sections. Da Vinci surgery 7/27/15, cath removed 8/4/15. First PSA post-op is zero (10/27/15) Second PSA is zero (6/29/16) Third PSA is zero (12/20/16) Fourth PSA is zero (7/1/17) Fifth PSA is zero (1/11/18 virtually no incontinence issues, sex life pretty much back to normal (wife & I are happy with that one )
Posts.Title: My First Zero came today

Posts.Content: Congrats! My first one took its own sweet time too...and it was such a relief when it did finally pass...The 8 days with the catheter were the longest of my life...THAT was a great day, when the catheter was removed...here's hoping your days pass swiftly and complication free.

Posts.Title: My First Zero came today

Posts.Content: on July 27th, 2015 I had robotic surgery to remove my prostate and the cancer that had been detected there...it has been quite a year since...I have made what I think is a great recovery, 2 zero PSA's, resumption of pretty much normal life as I knew it, and the kinship of brethren here who helped me in that journey. Oh yes,...I also have welcomed a new granddaughter into our family as well , our 4th grandchild, but our first granddaughter...God is good. I appreciate all of the help, encouragement, comments, and well wishes from everyone during my recovery...it has meant more than you could know.
Posts.Signature: 55 years old (born in 1962) PSA 5.6 (2nd PSA >4 in 12 months) Feb 2015. Biopsy 4/1/15, G (3+3) 6. 1 of 8 sections. Da Vinci surgery 7/27/15, cath removed 8/4/15. First PSA post-op is zero (10/27/15) Second PSA is zero (6/29/16) Third PSA is zero (12/20/16) Fourth PSA is zero (7/1/17) Fifth PSA is zero (1/11/18 virtually no incontinence issues, sex life pretty much back to normal (wife & I are happy with that one )
Posts.Title: One year ago today, 7/27/15, my world changed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Runlikewind Hey Wishbonedays, Question for you. What type of work do you do? Im scheduled for DiVinci soon and been asking questions about anticipated time away from work. Comments have ranged from 3-4 weeks. For you it was 7 weeks so Im just curious as to how it was decided that 7 weeks was the appropriate time. Look forward to your reply. I had heard anywhere from 6-8 weeks anecdotally, but my urologist told me about 4 weeks, so that was my original plan...but everyone that I spoke with that had undergone the procedure pretty much told me that 4 weeks might not be enough, so I kinda figured 6 would be about right. I friend of mine had the same surgery 7 years ago. He & I are both Respiratory Therapists, so I know his work routine. However, he worked at a large acute care hospital at the time, so the activity level at his job was a bit higher than where I work...I work for a pediatric homecare company, so my level of activity may vary quite a bit from day to day...some days are spent mostly in my office at my desk, others may be spent almost entirely on the road, others may be doing teaching at the hospital, so the activity level is not as constant. But my friend went back after 4 weeks and his words were something like "my first day back, I'd been at work about an hour and all I could think was "My God what have I done?"...so I planned on 6...and it was about right...however, at the middle of week 5, I was having some persistent and not-so-mild pain at a couple of the incision sites, so I told my office that I was taking off an extra week...by the start of the 6th week, however, the pain was much better and I probably could have went on back after the 6th week, but I had already arranged it for the 7th week, so I just went with it...and I'm glad I did. It was good spending an extra week at home...no regrets in that regard. I just tried very hard to not to "push it" or over-do it and I think that strategy worked, softball game notwithstanding (see one of my earlier posts ). I hope this info helps and all the best with your surgery and recovery...I'm very glad I found this forum...its been a big help and source of info, as well as camaraderie. All the best!
Posts.Signature: 55 years old (born in 1962) PSA 5.6 (2nd PSA >4 in 12 months) Feb 2015. Biopsy 4/1/15, G (3+3) 6. 1 of 8 sections. Da Vinci surgery 7/27/15, cath removed 8/4/15. First PSA post-op is zero (10/27/15) Second PSA is zero (6/29/16) Third PSA is zero (12/20/16) Fourth PSA is zero (7/1/17) Fifth PSA is zero (1/11/18 virtually no incontinence issues, sex life pretty much back to normal (wife & I are happy with that one )
Posts.Title: Back to work

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman And the reality is, i was somewhat fatigued until about 2-2 1/2 months out of surgery. So everyone is different. Ditto that...I'm in that boat too...there are days that I feel like I've run a marathon...others, not as bad...but I agree, the energy level is slow in returning to the way it was.

Posts.Title: Back to work

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PDV Teaching is hard, hard work. I agree...I taught for 2 years at the University level, and 4 more years at a community college and, while I thoroughly enjoyed it, lecturing all day will absolutely drain you, and the prep time is a man-eater too. I taught in the respiratory therapist programs, so even though I was teaching in my chosen discipline, it was still hard work...and I went home afterwards and wondered why I was spent, LOL.
Posts.Signature: 55 years old (born in 1962) PSA 5.6 (2nd PSA >4 in 12 months) Feb 2015. Biopsy 4/1/15, G (3+3) 6. 1 of 8 sections. Da Vinci surgery 7/27/15, cath removed 8/4/15. Posts.Title: Back to work

Posts.Content: Well, yesterday was my first day back to work, exactly 7 weeks postop DaVinci surgery...all went well...everyone was very supportive and encouraging. I'm easing back into my duties and I'm trying to heed everyone's advice to "take it slow"...I'm doing just that...there's no need in getting in a hurry to get back to "normal", although there is no more "normal" at this point, but I'm getting pretty close. Day 2 is going pretty much the same, so we'll see how things go, but overall I'm encouraged by what I'm seeing & feeling. I was quite surprised how I felt about going back to work...I was almost depressed...almost...I had gotten quite comfortable staying home, sleeping until 8 or 8:30 everyday, living the life of leisure...I told my kids that this was a test run for what retirement would be like...except retirement won't come with a catheter! But I found that while I liked being at home, I determined that I couldn't afford it, LOL...I was fortunate enough to have a "cash cancer" policy that paid really quickly, so there were no financial worries as it related to being off from work, but it won't finance a retirement, so back to work I went. Looking forward to better and better days.

Posts.Content: Hello all...my status in the zero club was renewed back in July...but just now getting to post. Haven't been on line much... tragedy hit my household this summer...my wife & I lost our 24 year old son on July 9th, so its been a really rough summer and, to say the least, I have been quite distracted & otherwise occupied with all that has been involved with taking care of his final affairs, caring for the rest of my family, and finally going back to work. My urologist retired last spring, so the new one is following up pretty much like the old one was, so I'll see him again around the beginning of the new year. All the best.

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: Please forgive the repetition, as I posted this in a reply to another thread earlier, but I wasn't certain how many may see/read it. Here is my concern...I'm experiencing some tenderness in my right testicle. Nothing too dramatic, just enough to be a nuisance. Is there anyone else, this far removed from surgery that has experienced or is experiencing this? One other caveat...this seems to be occurring a few days after my wife & I have sex, but this time it seems to be hanging on for a couple of extra days. I thought I would give it a few more days before calling the doc, but its getting harder to ignore.

Posts.Title: Zero Club status still intact

Posts.Content: Hello all...it's been a while since I've posted...I have a question. To review, I have the DaVinci surgery July 2015, with a good outcome, in my opinion, and no real issues in the last 6 - 10 months. Last week my wife & I went to watch our grandson's soccer game and I sat on regular metal bleachers for the game (we forgot our stadium seats). After the game I was walking to the car and I noticed that I was having some discomfort. By the time I got to the car, it was almost unbearable. We cancelled our dinner plans and went home. I took some naproxin and retreated to my chair. This pain lasted a couple of days before it subsided to the point of not being on my mind. I assume that my sitting on the flat bleachers was the cause of it, of course, but I'd never experienced anything like this. Has anyone else had a similar experience/problem, especially this far out from their procedure?
Posts.Signature: 55 years old (born in 1962) PSA 5.6 (2nd PSA >4 in 12 months) Feb 2015. Biopsy 4/1/15, G (3+3) 6. 1 of 8 sections. Da Vinci surgery 7/27/15, cath removed 8/4/15. First PSA post-op is zero (10/27/15) Second PSA is zero (6/29/16) Third PSA is zero (12/20/16) Fourth PSA is zero (7/1/17) Fifth PSA is zero (1/11/18 virtually no incontinence issues, sex life pretty much back to normal (wife & I are happy with that one )
Posts.Title: Pain 1 year after DaVinci surgery

Posts.Title: Pain 1 year after DaVinci surgery

Posts.Content: Hey Folks...been a while since I've posted...thought I would share this...had my latest PSA, last week got the results and we're still at zero! The only complicating factor was that the office lost my results for a few days and when the nurse called me, and I've know her almost my whole life as we went to the same high school, her first words were, "Hey Greg, uh, its Sherri...you got a minute?"...well, these were the first word/tone I heard when she called me to tell me that my PSA had gone way up prior, the one that triggered the biopsy. Sort of scared me for a few seconds...but she just wanted to apologize for the delay and give me the results...afterwards I was fine, but I'll tell you, that first few seconds kinda made my gut tighten a bit...but all is well, thankfully so.
